data.title: Urban Coloradans are having fewer kids
data.meta_description: Plus: Why a Washington tribe won‚Äôt send wolves, Stone Canyon fire 100% contained, ballot measures don‚Äôt get the signatures and more
data.text:
Good morning, Colorado.

Whenever it rained in Madagascar ‚Äî which wasn‚Äôt often in the island‚Äôs drought-stricken southernmost region where I was living as a Peace Corps volunteer ‚Äî my neighbors would whistle and cheer while standing under their verandas watching the raindrops fall. School was canceled and little kids squealed in excitement, running outside with buckets to catch the falling water from the sky.

I felt like celebrating last night, too, as it stormed and rained for hours in Colorado Springs. It wasn‚Äôt a drought buster by any means, but I can only imagine the firefighters fighting flames in the foothills let out a cheer or two.

We‚Äôve got a packed Sunriser this morning, with everything from wildfires, wolves, birth rates and more. Let‚Äôs get to it.

THE NEWS

COLORADANS

Births in metro Denver are falling faster than much of the country. Here‚Äôs what it means for the future.

Denver County experienced the second-largest decline in births among the 100 most populous counties in the country from 2021 to 2022 ‚Äî the most recent year of county-by-county data available from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The number of babies born dropped 6.3%. To better understand the numbers, Erica Breunlin dug into the data and spoke to women who are opting to be childfree.

READ MORE

OUTDOORS

15 wolves promised to Colorado by a Washington tribe aren‚Äôt coming. Here‚Äôs why.

A Native American tribe in Washington that promised 15 wolves to Colorado has rescinded its offer. In explaining their decision, the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Nation said ‚Äúnecessary and meaningful consultation was not completed with the potentially impacted tribes‚Äù when Colorado created its wolf reintroduction plan. Tracy Ross has the details.

READ MORE

ENVIRONMENT

New draft of Colorado oil and gas rules guts key protection for impacted communities, green groups say

‚ÄúThe fact that so many in the industry lined up against this shows how big an issue this was and that ECMC staff completely caved.‚Äù

‚Äî Mike Freeman, an attorney with the nonprofit environmental law firm Earthjustice

A state commission cut a key proposed requirement that oil companies seeking to drill within 2,000 feet of homes must get the approval of residents living there. Activists say tearing out that vital protection, just a month before hearings begin, gives a big advantage to the oil companies. Mark Jaffe and Michael Booth have more.

READ MORE

WILDFIRE

Stone Canyon fire 100% contained as feds called in to investigate cause

After fully containing the Stone Canyon fire, which destroyed five structures and was linked to one death, officials are in full-on investigation mode to try to figure out what caused the blaze near Lyons. Feds were called in, alongside Boulder authorities, to collect the clues, Jennifer Brown reports.

READ MORE

Live wildfire updates: Stone Canyon fire fully contained as crews shore up lines on Alexander Mountain, Quarry fires.

ELECTIONS 2024

Proponents of 8 proposed Colorado ballot measures fail to turn in signatures by Monday‚Äôs deadline

The proponents of eight measures being pursued for Colorado‚Äôs November ballot ‚Äî many of which were being pushed by conservative activists ‚Äî failed to get enough signatures by Monday‚Äôs deadline. That means voters this fall won‚Äôt weigh in on whether to ban children assigned male at birth from participating in girl‚Äôs youth sports and whether the state should require voter approval for fees raising money for public transportation projects. Jesse Paul has more on the measures that failed.

READ MORE

Coloradan Jenna Ellis, a former Trump attorney, agrees to cooperate in Arizona fake electors case. Ellis had previously pleaded not guilty to fraud, forgery and conspiracy charges in the Arizona case. In exchange for her cooperation, charges will be dropped.

MORE NEWS

Families whose loved ones‚Äô bodies were left rotting in Colorado funeral home are owed $950 million, judge rules. The judgment is unlikely to be paid out since owners Jon and Carie Hallford have been in financial trouble for years, making it largely symbolic.

Colorado once again breaks tourism records with 31% increase in travelers in the last decade. Spending by tourists supported 188,000 jobs and generated $1.8 billion in state and local tax revenue last year.

THE COLORADO REPORT

Aurora apartment owner says cops let immigrant gang overrun a complex, but officials say neglect turned it into a slum. Aurora is moving to close the 99-unit complex as uninhabitable, saying that despite the owner‚Äôs claims of ‚ÄúVenezuelan gang activity‚Äù the apartment building has faced numerous court actions for safety code violations years before immigrants arrived.

‚Äî Sentinel Colorado

Castle Pines ‚Äúdistracted‚Äù by trademark fight before PGA tournament, VP says. Castle Pines Golf Club ‚Äî which prominently displays hummingbirds all over its facility ‚Äî is trying to stop longtime restaurateurs Mark and Jo Brinkerhoff from opening a lounge called ‚ÄúBar Hummingbird‚Äù inside their steakhouse in Castle Rock, claiming that PGA spectators could be confused into thinking it‚Äôs associated with the club.

‚Äî BusinessDen üîë

So you want to plant a tree on the Front Range? A new list can help you choose the right one. Here‚Äôs the story behind the Front Range Tree Recommendation List, curated by nursery and tree care professionals, academics from CSU and Denver Botanic Garden staff.

‚Äî KRCC

Landmark Chez Artiste to close this week in the latest blow to Denver‚Äôs film buffs. First the Esquire, now the Chez Artiste. Where will film snob kids in their 20s (as I was once upon a time) hang out now?

‚Äî Denverite

üîë = source has article meter or paywall

THE OPINION PAGE

COMMUNITY

Oil and gas reforms recently implemented by Interior Department will benefit Colorado‚Äôs outdoor recreation. Despite Colorado Rep. Lauren Boebert‚Äôs ill-considered bill, it is imperative the BLM‚Äôs rule is protected.

‚Äî Louis Geltman, Kent Ebersole and Jason Keith

The Colorado Sun is a nonpartisan news organization, and the opinions of columnists and editorial writers do not reflect the opinions of the newsroom. Read our ethics policy for more on The Sun‚Äôs opinion policy and submit columns, suggest writers or provide feedback at opinion@coloradosun.com.

SunLit

REVIEW

A secret liaison with a student led CU professor to live ‚ÄúSeparate Lives‚Äù

Mary Rippon was a groundbreaking professor at the University of Colorado ‚Äî the first woman to hold that position at CU and possibly the first at any state university. She also harbored a secret ‚Äî a student with whom she had a daughter ‚Äî and proceeded to keep her private life hidden, in contrast to her renown as a professor. As Silvia Pettem‚Äôs biography shows, that was a particularly fraught proposition in Victorian-era Boulder.

READ AN EXCERPT

Interview with the author. Pettem recounts how primary documents helped her uncover many details about Rippon‚Äôs life and convince her that the story needed to be told.

Stay dry out there.

‚Äî Olivia & the whole staff of The Sun

Corrections & Clarifications

Notice something wrong? The Colorado Sun has an ethical responsibility to fix all factual errors. Request a correction by emailing corrections@coloradosun.com.
